title: G7 pledges faster vaccine rollout to developing world
text:
We have made a few changes to the newsletter to highlight more prominently the big themes of 2021: the rollout of vaccines and the state of the global economy. We will also feature more data from our range of Covid-19 trackers.

We are curious to know what you think about the changes. If you have a moment, let us know at covid@ft.com. Thanks

Please do forward this newsletter to friends and colleagues who might find it valuable. Even if they are not subscribers to the Financial Times, they can read the newsletter — and all of the FT — free for 30 days. And if this has been forwarded to you, hello. Welcome and please sign up here

G7 leaders meet as African Union secures 300m Russian jabs

Leaders of the G7 group of rich democracies have vowed to boost the supply of vaccines to poorer countries, as Russia and China continue to make headway in “vaccine diplomacy”.

The virtual gathering, hosted by UK prime minister Boris Johnson and attended by Joe Biden, speaking at his first big international meeting as president, pledged new money for the global vaccine initiative.

Differences persist, however, over the pace of support to developing countries. In an exclusive FT interview, French president Emmanuel Macron said Europe and the US should urgently allocate 5 per cent of their current vaccine supplies. He warned of a “war of influence over vaccines”, with Russia and China filling a gap left by rich countries.

Although Biden's administration rejected Macron's proposal, with one official saying “our current focus is on vaccinating Americans”, it also said it would “almost immediately” donate $2bn to Covax, the global scheme for supplying vaccines to the developing world, with a further $2bn over the next two years.

Johnson wants the UK, which has ordered more than 400m vaccine doses for a population of 67m, to donate its surplus supply to poorer countries. He urged the G7 to step up its Covax funding, and the meeting concluded with total pledges to the scheme of $7.5bn.

Meanwhile, the African Union announced that it had secured 300m doses of Russia's Sputnik V vaccine, which has also been sold to countries including Algeria, Argentina and Brazil. China's two leading manufacturers, Sinopharm and Sinovac Biotech, have signed deals with countries including Indonesia, Egypt and the Philippines.

Hopes for a faster global vaccine rollout were boosted by the news that the jab made by BioNTech/Pfizer can be stored at between minus 15C and minus 25C instead of the minus 60C to minus 80C originally required, and by an Israeli study indicating that it is 85 per cent effective after a single dose.

At least one country intends to do without inoculations altogether: John Magufuli, president of Tanzania, has declared them dangerous and unnecessary, and said his country had largely escaped Covid-19 — to the alarm of experts in neighbouring states.

Global economy

Europe's manufacturers have recovered strongly from the pandemic this month, according to the IHS Markit purchasing managers' survey, as demand from Asia stimulates activity. But services experienced a downturn, with lockdown restrictions forcing many businesses to stay closed. Meanwhile, policymakers at the European Central Bank have committed to persist with stimulus measures, despite rising inflation.

Official figures show that the UK government ran a record deficit of £8.8bn last month, as chancellor Rishi Sunak hinted at the possibility of tax rises to “return the public finances to a more sustainable footing”. Further data showed a sharp fall in retail sales in January, while manufacturing activity hit a nine-month low.

Nearly a year on from the start of the pandemic, we can take stock of which economies have weathered it best, says economics editor Chris Giles. Countries that controlled the virus effectively took less of a hit, but having a large manufacturing sector also helped — factors that propelled China to the top of the 2020 economic performance table.

Business

Carmaker Renault suffered an €8bn loss in 2020 as the pandemic hit demand across Europe. The company warned that a global shortage of microchips — caused by surging demand for digital technology during lockdown — could force it to curb production by 100,000 vehicles this year. 

Reinsurance group Swiss Re reported a loss of $878m last year, its first since the 2008-09 financial crisis, with pandemic-related claims costing it $3.9bn. The company said that, were it not for Covid-19, it would have been on course to make a net profit of $2.2bn. 

Other companies delivered more upbeat results. Benefiting from the surge in online sales during lockdown, UK warehouse group Segro reported adjusted pre-tax profits of £296.5m in 2020, up 10.8 per cent on the previous year, and said that consumer habits were likely to have “changed irrevocably”. French luxury goods group Hermès posted a net profit of €1.4bn, helped by strong Chinese demand for its scarves and handbags.

Markets

Sterling reached $1.40 today, its highest level since 2018, as investors anticipated a strong economic recovery following the UK's rapid vaccination campaign. The currency — which fell to as low as $1.14 when the pandemic hit in March — has risen 2.4 per cent against the dollar and 3 per cent against the euro since the end of 2020.

Chinese stocks briefly hit a record high on Thursday as traders returned from the lunar new year holiday. The CSI 300 index touched 5,931 points, beating its 2007 record, before subsiding. Friday's trading was more muted, with an overall gain of 0.2 per cent.

Expectations of rising inflation, fuelled by loose Federal Reserve monetary policy and Joe Biden's proposed stimulus package, have boosted US bond yields, with the benchmark 10-year US Treasury reaching 1.3 per cent this week. That could pose a threat to buoyant US equity markets, say FT correspondents Aziza Kasumov and Colby Smith, with investors now scrambling to find the tipping point for equities. 

The essentials

As Britons wait for prime minister Boris Johnson to announce his plan for lifting lockdown, many are itching to book a vacation. They might regret doing so, warns consumer editor Claer Barrett, who advises readers to consider less risky alternatives. “Friends who live in interesting places, have second homes or gardens big enough to erect a family-sized tent in are fast becoming the most valuable contacts in your address book.”

Final thought

“How can I help?”: it is, writes Bill Gates, the question he is most often asked when discussing climate change. While it's hard to find a satisfying answer, there are ways to make a measurable difference to the climate — though as his new green manifesto makes clear, they will require business leaders who are willing to shoulder unfamiliar risks.
